The Giro dâ€™Italia exploding into life with exploits from Ben Healy (EF Education-EasyPost) and Derek Gee (Israel-Premier Tech), then last-day shenanigans from Ineos Grenadiersâ€™ Geraint Thomas as he led out Astana Qazaqstanâ€™s Mark Cavendish.

Jumbo-Visma became the first team in history to achieve a Grand Tour sweep thanks to PrimoÅ¾ RogliÄ, Jonas Vingegaard and Sepp Kuss. Ineos Grenadiersâ€™ Josh Tarling has particularly impressed this year, the 19-year-old British ITT Champion shining with a bronze medal in the Elite Menâ€™s World ITT Championship. His first win arrived on Stage 2 of the Renewi Tour, where he became the joint youngest WorldTour stage winner (alongside Remco Evenepoel, no less), as he was later crowned the European ITT Champion and closed his year with victory at the Chrono des Nations.

The end of a cycling season inevitably marks retirements too, with Thibaut Pinot (Groupama-FDJ), Greg van Avermaet (AG2R-CitroÃ«n) and Peter Sagan (Team TotalEnergies) all hanging up their cycling cleats. Or in the case of Sagan, just his road-specific ones.

This year was also not without its tragedy. The loss of Bahrain Victoriousâ€™ Gino MÃ¤der is so painful, and no doubt still felt by his family, friends and cycling fans worldwide. As youâ€™ll see in this article, his teammates are continuing to honour him, with post-stage tributes from Matej MohoriÄ and fundraising from Pello Bilbao.

Here are my choices for the ten most memorable moments from the 2023 menâ€™s pro season.

1. Matej MohoriÄ pours his heart out following Tour de France stage win

Stage 19, Tour de France, 21st July 2023

Winning isnâ€™t everything, but there are so many ways in which a cyclist can do just that. A solo attack from 50km out, an audacious group breakaway that outfoxes the bunch in the final kilometres, a tyre-width sprint victory. Some riders are forced to wait minutes for confirmation, suspended in a limbo of uncertainty, such is the closeness of their competitors at the line.

On one side of the scale is an eventually crowned victor, who explodes into the wide range of emotions they had been holding back â€“ screaming, celebrating, crying â€“ while on the other side sits someone who was so close, yet so far. Itâ€™s not often a cyclist uses their time to dissect this equation in their post-stage interview. Enter Bahrain-Victoriousâ€™s Matej MohoriÄ after winning Stage 19 of the 2023 Tour de France.

â€˜Sometimes you feel like you donâ€™t belong here,â€™ he said in the emotional scene. â€˜Everyone is so incredibly strong that you struggle to hold the wheel sometimes. You know the guy who is pulling is suffering just as much as you. Kasper [Asgreen, Soudal-QuickStep] went and heâ€™s so incredibly strong. He went on the attack yesterday and won the stage. To have the win and the determination to do it all over againâ€¦ you just feel like you donâ€™t belong here.

â€˜I followed him. I knew everything had to be perfect. I tried my best, not just for myself but also for Gino [MÃ¤der] and the team. Then at the end you almost feel like you betray them because you beat them to the line. The way professional sport is, everyone wants to win and obviously if I want to win, I need to take the wheel of Kasper and try to beat him on the line. At one point I felt sorry for Ben [Oâ€™Connor, AG2R CitroÃ«n Team] because I knew he had no chance in the sprint. but he still pushed to stay away because he also wants to contest the win even though he knows heâ€™s likely to lose.

â€˜I always know I can win a Tour de France stage because I have already won two. Iâ€™m strong enough but so are the other 150 guys. Iâ€™m not the only one who can win a Tour de France stage and every single rider at this moment would deserve a win. I saw the faces of those in the gruppetto the other day on Col de la Loze and you know what everyone is going through. I know how much a win can change your life and I wish everyone could win a Tour de France stage but itâ€™s just not possible and thatâ€™s cruel, no?â€™

To articulate such humanity in the heat of sports is an admirable quality indeed, and to express his conflicting emotions and empathy for his rivals contributed to one of the best, if not the best, interviews from a professional cyclist that I have ever seen. Itâ€™s something I will continue to think about for many years.

2. Geraint Thomas leads out Mark Cavendish to â€˜help a brother outâ€™ at the Giro dâ€™Italia

Stage 21, Giro dâ€™Italia, 28th May 2023

The role of a leadout man is simple (on paper). With their designated sprinter on their wheel, they give it their all to drop off their teammate who â€“ should things go to plan â€“ sprints to the victory. But Stage 21 of the Giro dâ€™Italia was different. Ineos Grenadiersâ€™ Geraint Thomas proved you donâ€™t have to be racing on the same squad to provide a successful leadout, and that a friendship extending across rival teams will do just fine.

In the chaos that preceded the sprint finish, Thomas spoke to Mark Cavendish (Astana Qazaqstan) just prior to the 2km-to-go point. He then hit the front to set a storming pace as Cavendishâ€™s teammate Luis LeÃ³n SÃ¡nchez latched onto his wheel, with Cavendish following. Thomas peeled away at the 1km mark. After that, no one could keep up with Cavendishâ€™s pace in the final metres, and the Manx Missile crossed the line in what was then his final Giro dâ€™Italia. (He has since signed a one-year extension.)

After the race, Thomas said to Eurosport, â€˜I saw he only had Luis LeÃ³n SÃ¡nchez with him and I thought, help a brother out.â€™

3. Pello Bilbao dedicates first Tour de France stage win to his late teammate Gino MÃ¤der

Stage 10, Tour de France, 11th July 2023

After the tragic loss of Bahrain Victoriousâ€™ Gino MÃ¤der, who died at the Tour de Suisse this year, his teammate Pello Bilbao honoured his memory by replicating MÃ¤derâ€™s charitable gestures. At the Tour de France, Bilbao donated â‚¬1 for every rider he finished ahead of on each stage towards replanting on deforested land. Bilbao said he would double the donation if he achieved a stage win.

Just one day later, this would be a reality. Bilbao was part of the successful breakaway on Stage 10 towards Issoire. It was a tense final kilometre, with Bilbao and Georg Zimmermann (IntermarchÃ©-Circus-Wanty) rejoined by their breakaway companions. Bilbao kicked away in the last 200m and stayed ahead to raise his arms in victory for his first Tour de France stage win.

â€˜I crossed the line and I just put out all the energy inside of me and remembered the reason for this victory, a special one â€“ for Gino,â€™ Bilbao said.

The teammates were close friends; MÃ¤der had adopted a stray dog in Bilbao and named him Pello.

4. Stars align for Thibaut Pinotâ€™s last attack at the Tour de France

Stage 20, Tour de France, 22nd July 2023

A perfect ride into retirement. During his final Tour de France, Groupama-FDJâ€™s Thibaut Pinot launched a solo attack on home roads in the Vosges mountains during Stage 20. Hundreds of his fans lined the roadside to Le Markstein Fellering, specifically over Le Petit Ballon and gathering on Virage Pinot â€“ the bend heralded as a place of worship on Google Maps, such is the almost religious dedication of those drawn to Pinotâ€™s riding.

Pinot had jumped from the chasing group and into the breakaway. It was here that he distanced ArkÃ©a-Samsicâ€™s Warren Barguil and Ineos Grenadiersâ€™ Tom Pidcock to cut a lone figure in the distance. Virage Pinot beckoned. The stars had aligned. Pinot was here. Surrounded by his family, friends and fan club.

He wouldnâ€™t win the stage, but the Frenchman crossed the line 33 seconds down on UAE Team Emiratesâ€™ Tadej PogaÄar. He might have liked a stage win, but it was still a send-off he could savour.

5. Ben Healy and Derek Gee top Vibes Classification for fighting spirit

Giro dâ€™Italia, 6th â€“ 28th May 2023

What is the Vibes Classication? Itâ€™s an informal classification throughout the season hosted by yours truly. To top the Vibes Classification in a Grand Tour requires a combination of combativity and chutzpah. Timings on general classification are irrelevant â€“ although Jumbo-Vismaâ€™s Sepp Kuss happened to win the general classification and my Vibes Classification at the Vuelta. You just need to possess a can-do spirit, an attacking ability and to err on the side of do rather than do not.

Ben Healy (EF Education-EasyPost) and Derek Gee (Israel-Premier Tech) were the entertainers of the Giro dâ€™Italia with a combined five stage combativity awards. Springboarding off a prosperous Classics campaign with second places in Brabantse Pijl and the Amstel Gold Race, Healy lit up the Giro with boundless energy and abandon. His win on Stage 8 over two ascents of I Cappuccini was the result of a 50km solo breakaway. He couldnâ€™t be contained, seen jostling with Pinot for a KoM duel on Stage 19 too as Jumbo-Vismaâ€™s Rohan Dennis laughed on.

Meanwhile Gee had people renaming the race the Gee-ro dâ€™Italia with his determination and â€˜why not?â€™ attitude. Second places on Stage 10, 14 and 19 may have thrust him into a Sep Vanmarcke style always-the-bridesmaid position, but his enthralling persistence on a day-to-day level earned him three combativity awards and the overall prize to boot.

6. Sepp Kuss battles teammates to win the Vuelta a EspaÃ±a in unpredictable and enthralling scenes

Vuelta a EspaÃ±a, 26th August â€“ 17th September 2023

Given the strength of their line-up at the start of the Vuelta a EspaÃ±a, you probably couldâ€™ve guessed that a Jumbo-Visma rider would win the last three-week race of the season. But Sepp Kuss over Jonas Vingegaard or PrimoÅ¾ RogliÄ? Now thatâ€™s a story.

I penned an article after his victory that saluted the loyal domestique thrust into his new and sudden leadership role, one that would earn him the title of becoming the first American in over a decade to win a Grand Tour. But to think back to the race itself: the anticipation of him probably relinquishing the jersey further down the line, the suspension when it didnâ€™t happen and the race was speeding towards its finale in the final week, the pitchforks when Kuss was dropped by his teammates on Stage 17â€™s Alto de Lâ€™Angliru, the realisation that, yes, after everything, it would be Kuss on the top step of the podiumâ€¦ what a wonderfully cinematic Vuelta a EspaÃ±a that was. My thoughts have already been said: â€˜riders working together during a Grand Tour as their teammate is in the red jersey isÂ not a giftÂ â€“ itâ€™s what teams are supposed to do.â€™

Kuss won the Vuelta a EspaÃ±a anyway with help (and one climb of hindrance?) from his teammates as Jumbo-Visma became the first team to win all three Grand Tours in one season.

7. A resurgent John Degenkolb rolls back the years during Paris-Roubaix

Paris-Roubaix Hommes, 9th April 2023

An early season sprinkle of nostalgia. For there, contending at the fastest-ever Paris-Roubaix, was 34-year-old John Degenkolb of DSM-Firmenich. The man who had won the race back in 2015 had made the contending group in 2023 over the punishing cobblestones.

On the five-star Carrefour de lâ€™Arbre secteur, eventual winner Mathieu van der Poel (Alpecin-Deceuninck) rode around his teammate Jasper Philipsen as Degenkolb was passing through along the â€˜smootherâ€™ side to his right. Philipsen then moved slightly right, Van der Poel veered towards Degenkolb and down Degenkolb went. He was back on his bike quickly enough, but the damage was already done. Degenkolb finished in tears, crossing the line in 7th and 2min 35sec down, describing it as a â€˜racing incidentâ€™. His performance at Paris-Roubaix was one of his best in years.

8. PrimoÅ¾ RogliÄ exorcises Grand Tour ITT demons at the Giro dâ€™Italia

Stage 20, Giro dâ€™Italia, 27th May 2023

The image of Jumbo-Vismaâ€™s PrimoÅ¾ RogliÄ riding his way to the Giro dâ€™Italia victory, surrounded by home support and Slovenian flags (Stage 20 was also prophetically close to the border) is one for the history books. The Stage 20 ITT towards Monte Lussari was brutal, delivering sections up to 25%. It was a unique and strange affair, prime for late race dramatics â€“ a bike exchange point, no vehicles allowed near the top of the climb and a return to base via a ski lift.

RogliÄ lost the 2020 Tour de France when he imploded on La Planche des Belles Filles, a time-trial that UAE Team Emiratesâ€™ Tadej PogaÄar rode to perfection to claim overall victory. Yet he would flip the script this time, no matter how hard a mechanical tried to thwart him. This boisterous mountain time-trial performance, winding his way to the finish through flares and roaring fans, would overhaul then-leader Geraint Thomas (Ineos Grenadiers) for the maglia rosa. A ride for the ages.

9. Four big hitters take centre stage during Glasgow Worlds

UCI Menâ€™s Road Race World Championship, 6th August 2023

The World Championships. The best of the best. How fitting that in the elite menâ€™s event, we would see Mathieu van der Poel (Netherlands), Tadej PogaÄar (Slovenia), Wout van Aert (Belgium) and Mads Pedersen (Denmark) chasing towards Italyâ€™s Alberto Bettiol. The cream of the crop had risen on the tough Glaswegian circuit.

Not without its drama though. Van der Poel attacked in the final 22km and looked set for certain victoryâ€¦ until he slid out in a puddle-splattered corner. Cameras zoomed in on his broken shoe, ripped skinsuit and bloodied knee. No matter â€“ this is Van der Poel. He still managed to solo away to the finish line and be crowned menâ€™s World Champion.

As weâ€™re talking four big hitters â€“ remember Van der Poel, PogaÄar, Van Aert and Ineos Grenadiersâ€™ Filippo Ganna at Milan-San Remo?

10. Yates brothers establish twin breakaway in dramatic Tour de France opener

Stage 1, Tour de France, 1st July 2023

The Tour de France began in Bilbao, Basque County. A decisive group formed on the front and UAE Team Emiratesâ€™ Adam Yates attacked from it, drawing out none other than his very own twin brother, Simon Yates of Jayco-AlUla. The two pedalled away in their brotherly breakaway, holding off a late Jumbo-Visma chase to fight for the first yellow jersey of the race. Yates (Adam) distanced his brother Yates (Simon) in the last kilometre, taking the stage win and the jersey. The duo hugged after the line.

â€˜I donâ€™t even know what to sayâ€¦ my brother came across to me and we started working together,â€™ Adam Yates said. â€˜At first I didnâ€™t know if I should, I asked on the radio and they said go for it.â€™

This is why I watch cycling. What a combination of phenomenal moments throughout the season. I canâ€™t wait to see what 2024 brings.
